div.p: idānīṃ cakrānām anukramaḥanukramaanukramā kathyatekathyaṃte/ Once again Rāmacandra presents descriptions of the cakras, but this time very brief covering merely the names and locations of each cakra. Given their detailled description in chapters 4 12 it seems redundant to mention them once again at this place. Either we could assume that Rāmacandra was a very thoughtless and unstructured author/compiler, or this phenomenon must be taken as a further indication that Rāmacandra had an educational intention for his audience and that this text was used as a textbook so that he immediately used the preceding verse to repeat the sequence of the cakra system that he already discussed in detail at the beginning of the text.ādhāreādhāro brahmacakrambrahmacakraṃ 1 // ādhāropariom. liṅgamūleliṅge svādhiṣṭhānacakramsvādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ 2 // nābhau maṇipūrakacakrammaṇipūrakacakraṃ 3 // hṛdaye 'nāhataanāhata°viśuddha°cakramcakraṃ 4 //[5] kaṇṭhasthāne viśuddhicakramanāhatacakraṃ 5 // ṣaṣṭhaṃṣaṣṭha° tālucakramtālucakraṃtālucakretālucakra 6 // bhruvor madhye ājñāagnejaāgneyaājñāyacakraṃcakram 7 // brahmarandhraom.sthāne kālabrahma°cakramcakraṃ 8 // navamam ānavamanavamaṃ rattunavamaṃkāśacakramcakraṃ 9 //[10] tat paetattataḥtatarama°paraṃpara°śūnyam°śūnyaṃtatparamaśūnyaṃ//

Now the sequence of the cakras is taught. At the supportIn the previous section on cakras Rāmacandra situates the first cakra, which he there calls mūlacakra, at the beginning (ādau) [of supposedly the central channel], which should be at the anus if we assume an ascending order, cf. p.. This assumption is further supported by the additional descriptions of U2 folio 2v. l.2 in which it is explicitly located at the anus (gudasthānam) and called ``ādhāracakra'' (``cakra of the support''). Thus, the location presented here as ādhāre (``at the support'') should be understood as mūlādhāre (``at the root support'')., there is the Brahmacakra. Above the support at the root of the gender is the Svadiṣṭhānacakra. At the navel, there is the Maṇipūrakacakra. In the heart [there is] the Anāhatacakra.[5] Situated within the throat is the Viśuddhicakra. The sixth is the Tālucakra. In the centre of the eyebrows is the Ājñācakra. At the opening of BrahmaThe brahmarandhrasthāne (``at the place of the aperture of Brahmā/Brahman'') is the fontanelle, through which the vital principle of the yogi exists at death, cf. rootsofyoga2017. is the KālacakraI have not been able to identify the term ``kālacakra'' (``cakra of time'') for the eighth cakra in other texts. All other texts that I am aware of designate the eighth cakra in a ninefold cakra system with different terms: peterson1888 4359/256.13 calls it nirvāṇa° (``absolute extinction''); shivayogapradipika 3.15 also designates it with nirvāṇa°; the ssplonavla 2.8 again calls it the nirvāṇacakraṃ; Yogasvarodaya as quoted in ramatosana (Ed. p. 833) only calls it aṣṭamaṃ cakraṃ (``the eighth cakra'') and siddhapuṃsaḥ sthalaṃ (``place of the accomplished human''); Rāmacandra himself in the previous chapter on cakras in 11.1 picks this up and calls it aṣṭamacakraṃ (``eighth cakra'') and siddhapuruṣasya sthānaṃ (``place of the accomplished person''); Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 2 3) calls it siddhapuruṣasyānacakraṃ (``the cakra of the accomplished person''); saubhagya again calls it nirvāṇacakram, but provides us with yet another unique designation parabrahmacakram (``cakra of the supreme Brahmā/Brahman''). The ninth is the ĀkāśacakraThe term ākāśacakra for the ninth cakra in the known ninefold cakra systems only occurs in shivayogapradipika 3.16 and ssplonavla 2.9.[10] It is supreme emptiness.

kathyantekathyantakathyate/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 839): aṅguṣṭhapādayos tejaḥ salakṣasthiradṛṣṭimān | pādāṅguṣṭhe ya ādhāraḥ prathamo (prathamaṃ YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.16 Ed. p. 24) yogatattvataḥ |SSP 2.10 (Ed. p. 32): tatra prathamaḥ pādāṅguṣṭhādhāraḥ | tatrāgratas tejomayaṃ dhyāyet | dṛṣṭiḥ sthirā bhavati |prathamaḥ pādāṅguṣṭhādhāraḥom.// Judging by the sources and parallels for this passage as well as the introductory statements Rāmacandra presents for the following ādhāras, it appears likely that originally the first ādhāra was introduced, too.pādayor aṃguṣṭheaṃguṣṭhai tejasotejasaṃ lakṣyalakṣa°lakṣaṃ kartavyaṃkāraṇāt°karaṇāt dṛṣṭiḥdṛṣṭi°sthirā bhavatibhavatī/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 839): dvitīyaṃ pādamūlan tu pādamūlaparaṃ (pādamūlaṃ paraṃ YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.16 Ed. p. 24) sa vai | pādasya pārṣṇī (pārṣṇi YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.17a, Ed. p. 24) saṃsthāpya balavān prabhaven muniḥ | pādamūle 'thavā pādāṅguṣṭhamūlaṃ (pṛṣṭhe pādāṅguṣṭhe YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.17 Ed. p. 24) vidhārayet ||SSP pārṣṇiḥ°pārṣṇīḥdhāraḥ pādāṃduṣṭhasya mūleḥ parapādasya pārṣṇiḥ sthāpyatesyāpyatesthāyyaṃte tadāgniḥagni°agniḥom. prabaloom. bhavatibhavatīom./[5] ekāekaḥekāṃ pārṣṇir mūpārṣṇiḥpārṣṇir ādaulādhāremūlādhāramūlādhārāmūlādhārai sthāpyate/ Sentence om.in N2 and U2.Sentence om.in U2.tasya pādasyāṅguṣṭhamūlepādasya aṃguṣṭhamūlaṃ parasyaaparasya pādasyaom. pārṣṇiḥpārṇipārṣṇo sthāpyatesthāpyaṃ/ tadagniḥtadagnīḥagniragni pradīpyatepradipyatedīpyatedāpyatedīpate/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 839): tṛtīyan tu gudādhāro (gudādhāre YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.18 Ed. p. 24) gudasaṅkocanakriyā | vikāśākuñcanaṃ tasya sthiravāyau ca mṛtyujit |SSP 2.12 (Ed. p. 33): tṛtīyo gudādhāra taṃ vikāsasaṃkocanena nirākuñcayet | apānavāyuḥ sthiro bhavati |tṛṭīyaṃtṛtīya gudādhārasthānaṃ°sthāne// tanmadhye saṃkocavikāśā°vikāśa°kuṃcanaākuṃcanaakuṃcanakuṃcanaṃkāraṇāt papavanaḥpavana° sthiro bhavatibhavatī/[10] anu caanyac caanūcaanucara°anucakra° puruṣasya maraṇaṃ naom. bhavatibhavatī/

Now the divisions of the totalityI propose to understand cakra here in the less common meaning of "troup, crowd, totality", cf. petersburger. of supportsThe yogic practice of sixteen ādhāras goes back to more ancient yoga traditions of Śaivism and is mentioned in texts such as tantraloka, manthana and netratantra. It appears that the techniques were passed on and recycled across the centuries among yoga traditions of Haṭha and Rājayoga. Besides Rāmacandra's text the other texts which present full lists of the sixteen ādhāras are: Netroddyota commentary of Kṣemarāja on Netratantra 7.5; sarada 25.24 25; shivayogapradipika 3.17 33; ssplonavla 2.10 25; yogatarangini 1.13 (Ed. p. 72 73) quotation with reference ``nityanāthapaddhatau'' (maybe another recension of the ssplonavla, see shivayogapradipika); hathatattvakaumudi 24.10 23; and jyotsna on hathapradipika2024, as well ramatosana (Ed. p. 839 841) quotation with reference ``yogasvarodaye'' and yogakarnika quotation with reference ``yogasvarodaye'' 14 36. Comparing the various lists of ādhāras reveals a significant variability. Rāmacandra's system is certainly derived from the Yogasvarodaya. This passage additionally suggests clear influences from the ssplonavla. As shivayogapradipika discussed, the shivayogapradipika was probably the source text of the ssplonavla. [for concentration] are taught.Most of the previously mentioned cakras overlap with the ādhāras, except for the ākāśacakra. The first is the support at the big toe. From the execution of the fixation onto the light at the big toe of the feet stability of the gaze arises.In all previously mentioned systems the big toe is the first ādhāra. In most texts the practicioner is instructed to fixate the mind onto the big toe either one shall visualize a light there (as in shivayogapradipika) or the light is already present. sarada, however, instructs to fix prāṇa (the practitioner holds mind and breath at the respective locations) onto each ādhāra listed. Here, the practice of the adhāras is subsumed under the dhāraṇā limb in an eight fold (aṣṭāṅga) yoga system. The remainder of texts simply lists the adhāra without further instructions. The root support is the second [one]. The heel of the other foot is caused to be placed at the root of the big toe. As a result the fire is strengthened.[5] One heel is caused to be placed at the Root container. The heel of the other foot is caused to be placed at the root of the big toe of this foot. The fire of it is caused to be kindled.Either the text is corrupted here or Rāmacandra did not understand the Yogasvarodaya. This might have caused him to addionally draw from the description of the ssplonavla hhich resulted in the two separate descriptions. Netroddyota, sarada and jyotsna give the ankle (gulpha) as the second adhāra. The third is the location of the anus support. From the execution of expansion and contraction a stable vitalwind arises.[10] And therefore death of the person does not arise.Netroddyota, sarada and jyotsna provide the knee (jānu) as the third adhāra.

bhavet tena sādhayet tu sadā yuvā | mūlādhāre brahmapadme ṣaṭpadme ca tathā tathā |SSP 2.13 (Ed. pp. 33 34): caturtho meḍhrādhāraḥ | liṅgasaṃkocanena brahmagranthitrayaṃ bhitvā bhramaraguhāyāṃ viśramya tata ūrdhvamukhe bindustambhanaṃ bhavati| eṣā vajrolī prasiddhācaturthaṃcaturtha° liṅgādhāraṃ // tanmadhye liṅgasaṃkocanāsakoṇā°bhyāsāt pa t papaścimapaścīma°paścama°daṇḍamadhye vajravajñā°prajñā°nāḍī bhavatibhavatī/[14] tanmadhye punar ābhyāsakaraṇān makaraṇātnaḥpunaḥ pavanayoḥpavanayo saṃcārosaṃcoro bhavatibhavatī/ tayoḥtayo saṃcārān masaṃcārātdhye granthitrayaṃ yuvaivayuvāyuveyuvaiyuve vayurvaivayuvaivaṃyuvaivaṃ bhavatibhavatīprabhavati/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 840): pañcamaṃ jaṭharādhāraṃ tadā bandhayati kramāt | mṛtyunā bhaṅgasiddho 'yaṃ (mṛtyunā māṅga° YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.23 Ed. p. 25) mṛtyor (mṛtyur YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.23 Ed. p. 25) eva kṣayaṅkaraḥ | anena paścimād ūrddhaṃ (ūrdhvaṃ YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.24 Ed. p. 25) vāyuḥ kuryād viśāladhīḥ | bandho 'yaṃ buddhimanasoḥ pañcamādhārakālajit |SSP 2.14 (Ed. p. 34): pañcame oḍīyāṇādhārayor bandhanān malamūtrasaṃkocanaṃ bhavati | *uḍyānā° etc. in various mss.paṃcamaṃpaṃcamapaṃcam uḍḍīyāṇaṃ svādhiṣṭhānaṃudyānaṃodyānaṃuddyānaṃuḍḍīyāṇāṃ svādhiṣṭhānaṃuḍḍiyānāṃ svādhiṣṭhānaṃudgīryāṇāṃ svādhiṣṭhānaṃ // Spellings for this component of the yogic body vary across yogic literature. B, E, L, P, U2 add the expression svādhiṣṭhānaṃ which was associated with the pīṭha in chapter 5.1.tatra bandhanān mabadhadānānbaṃdhanātvaṃdhanātbaṃdhadānātbaṃdhadānānbaṃdha dīyatelamūtrayor nāmūlamūcayorśo bhavatibhavatī/

The fourth is the penis support. Due to the execution of repeated practice of contracting the penis in the center of it, the adamantine channelThe adamantine channel (vajranāḍī) is another synonym for the central channel. Rāmacandra adapted the term from the Yogasvarodaya. yogatarangini in the commentary on 1.13 uses the term vajragarbha, ``the adamantine womb''. appears in the middle of the staff of the backThe staff of the back (paścimadaṇḍa) is the central channel, cf. peterson1888 4365.. From the repeated practice again [and again], both breath and mind move into its center. Caused by the transition of both [breath and mind] into the center [of the adamantine channel] the trinity of knotsThe trinity of knots are: 1. the knot of Brahmā/Brahman (brahmagranthi) usually situated in the lower regions of the body (cf. liersch2023 23 24); 2. the knot of Viṣṇu (viṣṇugranthi) at the level of the heart (cf. liersch2023 25 and gsatacod 80); and 3. the knot of Rudra (rudragranthi) at the level of the head or between the eyebrows (cf. liersch2023 25 and gsatacod 81). Depending on text and tradition, it is either the breath (cf. asiddhi 13.9 11) or the kuṇḍalinī (cf. yogabija 96 7 and gsatacod 74 86) that enters the central channel and pierces the knots. It remains uncertain if knots are supposed to be something physical or mental. gsatacod 48 states that the entrance to the central channel is blocked by phlegm (physical) and, in the same breath, mentions that the three knots have arisen from the three guṇas, which might be interpreted as physical or mental. Nevertheless, the three knots in yoga texts, in one way or another, obstruct the central passage. breaks. There, from the breaking of that, the vital wind, after having filled up (the central channel?), resides within the lotus of Brahmā/BrahmanThe lotus of Brahmā/Brahman refers to the eighth cakra in Rāmacandra's system, cf. chapter 8, p. . The same location is expressed in the ssplonavla 2.13 and yogatarangini commentary on 1.13 with the term ``buzzing hive'' (brahmaraguhā) usually situated on top of the head (jogpradipyaka 932; cf. peterson1888 4366 and gorakbhani 28.2 and 30.4).. From that, virility and strength arise. The person becomes youthful forever.Most of the consulted texts situate the fourth adhāra at the penis (meḍhra). sarada and jyotsna place the fourth support at the thighs (ūru). shivayogapradipika 3.20 and ssplonavla 2.13 additionally associate the practice with the arrest of semen (bindustambha). However, just ssplonavla calls this vajrolī. The fifth is Uḍḍīyāna at the Svādiṣṭhāna[cakra]For a further discussion of the term uḍḍiyāṇa, see p. fn. 23.. From performing bandha there, urine and faeces disappear.shivayogapradipika, ssplonavla and yogatarangini share the concept of performing a bandha at the location of Uḍḍīyāna. hathatattvakaumudi instructs to do a pressing (moṭana) at the waist (kaṭau). Netroddyota, along with sarada and jyotsna situate the fifth adhāra at the anus (pāyu or sīvanī), whereas the Yogasvarodaya situates the fifth adhāra at the belly (jaṭharādhāra) and provides details (cf. sources) not reflected in Rāmacandra's text. This strongly indicates that Rāmacandra relies more on the ssplonavla at this point.

bhavati |PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 840): saptamo hṛdayādhāras tasmin vāyunibandhanāt | ūrddhaktrāṇi (ūrdhvavaktrāṇi YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.26 Ed. p. 25) padmāni vikasanti mahān bhavet |saptamoom. aṣṭame kaṇṭhādhāre kaṇṭhamūlaṃ cibukena nirodhayet | iḍāpiṅgalayor vāyuḥ sthiro bhavati |aṣṭamaḥaṣṭamaṃaṣṭameaṣṭama° kaṇṭhādhāraḥ/ tatratatraḥ jālaṃdharojālaṃdhara°jalaṃ bandho dīyatedīpyate/[25] tasmin satīḍāyāṃsatīyāṃsati iḍāyāṃsatiśadāyāṃ piṅgalāyāṃ pavanaḥpavana° sthiro bhavatibhavatī/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 840): navamo ghaṇṭikādhāras tatra jihvāgramagrataḥ (jihvāgrataḥ kṛte YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.28 Ed. p. 25) | sampivatyamṛtaṃ tasmād yogajinmṛtyujitparaḥ |SSP 2.18 (Ed. p. 35): navame ghaṇṭikādhāre jihvāgraṃ dhārayet | amṛtakalā sravati |navamonavo ghaṃṭikāghaṭikā°ghaṃṭā°dhāraḥdhāras/ tatra jihvāgraṃjihvāyāgraṃjuhvāyāṃ lagnaṃ bhavatibhavatībhavati vā/ tatotataḥ 'mṛtakalāyāmṛtakalāyāṃamṛtakalāyāḥ amṛtaṃamṛtaom. sravatiom./ tadamṛtapānāc chatadamṛtapānāttadamṛtakalāyāṃ amṛtapānī°amṛtapānātadamṛtapānārīraśarīra°madhye rogasaṃcāro naom. bhavatibhavatī/[30] PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 840): daśamas tālukādhāras tatra jihvāgrataḥ kṛte (hemistich om. YKqcr \cdot YSV | calane dohane caiva jihvā jaḍati lambitā (jāyeta lambitam YKqcr \cdot YSV 2.28cd Ed. p. 25) | nāsikāprāptajihveyaṃ tālulagnā bhavet tataḥ |SSP 2.19 (Ed. p. 35): daśame tālvādhāre tālvantar garbhe lambikāṃ cālanadohanābhyāṃ dīrghīkṛtvā viparītena praveśayet | kāṣṭhībhavati |daśamas tādaśamaṃsdaśamaṃdaśamalvādhāraḥ/ tanmadhyestaṃnmadhye cālanaṃcānanaṃvānaṃ dohanaṃdollahanaṃdohanaṃ chedanaṃ ca kṛtvākratvāsva kṛtvā laṃbikācālaṃ vikāpraveśe satiśe satigrati tālunimagnātālūnimagnātālumagnā jihvājuhvāom. tiṣṭhatiom./

The sixth is the support of the navel. From the repeated practice of praṇava, the unstruck sound arises by itself.A comparative look reveals significant differences among the text that teach the sixteen adhāras. ssplonavla instructs recitation of oṃ at the navel, yogatarangini adds meditation on the form of consciousness (cidrūpam) to the recipe, whereas in hathatattvakaumudi the breath should be restrained at the navel, which rises the sound of oṃ into emptiness. From here, the text instructs to move the mind to the heart center, enabling consciousness to blossom. In the Yogasvarodaya, the restraint of breath in the navel causes the nāda to arise automatically. However, shivayogapradipika instructs to contemplate Kuṇḍalinī at the navel. Netroddyota lists the kanda four fingers below the navel as the sixth support. The seventh is the support of the heart form. From the restraint of the Prāṇa vitalwind in this location also the six upward facing lotusses open up. The throat support is the eighth. There the binding of JālaṅdharaWrite about the pīṭha and the bandha! is produced.[25] While abiding therein the vitalwind in the Iḍā and Piṅgalā channel becomes stable. The ninth is the support of the uvula. There the tip of the tongue becomes attached [to the uvula]. Because of that the nectar of immortality flows from the immortality digit. From drinking the nectar of immortality diseases do not spread in the body.[30] The tenth is the support of the palate. After the moving and milking has been done therein, [and] while abiding at entrance of the uvula, the tongue resides inserted within the palate.
